statement.p: An aircraft in flight has total energy given by \displaystyle{E}_{{T}}=\frac{{1}}{{2}}{m}{v}^{{2}}+{m}{g}{h} where
\displaystyle{m} is the mass of the aircraft in pounds
\displaystyle{h} is the height above sea level in feet

Suppose a glider with mass \displaystyle{1131} lbs and initial velocity \displaystyle{87.0} ft/s is at an altitude of \displaystyle{5000}. ft MSL. If the pilot wants to increase the velocity to \displaystyle{117.0} ft/s to what altitude must it descend? ft MSL
Round according to the rules for measurements.
Hint: The total energy will be the same before and after the altitude change.

solution.p: To solve for a new altitude we will need to know the total energy. We can calculate that from the initial conditions.
